questions.text: A 44 yr old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. During examination, you note that patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features, and prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening method for this condition ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin like growth factor 1 binding potein -3 (IGFBP-3 )

questions.correct_answer: C. Insulin like growth factor -1 levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Insulin like growth factor-1 levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serum IGF-1 is the preferred initial test for screening acromegaly due to its reliability and the persistence of elevated levels in the presence of excessive GH production. This test provides a stable indicator of disease activity and is less variable than direct GH measurements.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 10^5 IU/mL and ALT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.
  • ➤ Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.

questions.text: FISH is used to detect all of the following except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Point mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH is a cytogenetic technique used to detect chromosomal-level changes such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions but is not capable of detecting point mutations at the nucleotide level

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nitrates provide symptomatic relief in Prinzmetal angina through endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation, which helps to alleviate coronary artery spasms and restore proper blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Although cabergoline is often used for prolactinomas due to better tolerability and efficacy, it is not the preferred agent when fertility is desired, especially around the time of conception or planned pregnancy.
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • According to endocrine guidelines:
  • • Bromocriptine has been safely used for over 30 years in women trying to conceive, with no proven teratogenicity.
  • • Once pregnancy is confirmed, bromocriptine is discontinued to reduce fetal exposure.
  • • Cabergoline, being long-acting with high D₂ receptor affinity, is not recommended during conception planning, due to less extensive safety data in pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cabergoline : Not preferred in women desiring fertility due to longer half-life and limited pregnancy safety data.
  • • Option A. Cabergoline
  • • Option C. Octreotide : A somatostatin analog used for GH-secreting tumors (e.g., acromegaly), not prolactinomas.
  • • Option C. Octreotide
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant : GH receptor antagonist for acromegaly; no role in prolactinoma or fertility.
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women with microprolactinoma and infertility, bromocriptine is the first-line treatment to restore ovulation and promote safe conception. While cabergoline is effective and often better tolerated, it is not the agent of choice when pregnancy is desired, due to concerns regarding its longer action and limited pregnancy safety data.

questions.text: Which of the following infections presents with a rash that characteristically spreads from the extremities towards the center of the body? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Epidemic typhus is characterized by a rash that starts on the upper trunk, usually on the fifth day, and then becomes generalized, involving the entire body except the face, palms, and soles. This rash begins peripherally and moves centrally, which is the hallmark of a non-centrally distributed rash.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Measles : The rash of measles begins as erythematous macules behind the ears and on the neck and hairline. The rash progresses to involve the face, trunk, and arms, with involvement of the legs and feet by the end of the second day. This distribution does not describe a non-centrally distributed rash.
  • • Option B. Measles
  • • Option C. Secondary syphilis : The skin rash of secondary syphilis typically involves the entire body, including the palms and soles. This rash is not specifically non-centrally distributed.
  • • Option C. Secondary syphilis
  • • Option D. Typhoid : Typhoid fever presents with rose spots primarily on the trunk and chest. The distribution of these rose spots does not align with a non-centrally distributed rash.
  • • Option D. Typhoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Epidemic typhus is distinguished by a rash that starts peripherally and moves centrally, making it a non-centrally distributed rash.

questions.text: Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? ( INICET MAY 2023) DiGeorge syndrome Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Complement deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.
  • ➤ However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a history of fall 1 year back with parietal bone fracture, has now presented with a painful and growing parietal swelling. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Growing fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A growing fracture is a rare but serious condition in young children, often presenting as a growing swelling over a skull fracture site within a year of the initial injury. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: These findings are suggestive of which of the following conditions
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The images provided show a patient with coarse facial features, prognathism (protruding jaw), frontal bossing (prominent forehead), and prominent jaw bones. These are characteristic features of acromegaly, a condition caused by excessive growth hormone (GH) production, usually due to a pituitary adenoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Addison's disease: Characterized by hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and weight loss, not by coarse facial features.
  • • Option A. Addison's disease:
  • • Option B. Gigantism: Also caused by excess GH, but it occurs before the closure of the growth plates in children and adolescents, leading to increased height and growth of long bones. The facial features are not as prominent as in acromegaly.
  • • Option B. Gigantism:
  • • Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Characterized by features such as central obesity, moon face, buffalo hump, and purple striae, not by coarse facial features and prognathism.
  • • Option D. Cushing's syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acromegaly is diagnosed based on characteristic facial features such as coarse facial features, prognathism, and frontal bossing, resulting from excessive growth hormone production.

questions.text: The enzyme that is common for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphoglycerate kinase is a common enzyme in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, catalyzing a reversible reaction that interconverts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate.
  • ➤ Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:
  • ➤ Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:
  • ➤ Phosphoglycerate mutase Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase Triose phosphate isomerase Aldolase Phosphohexose isomerase
  • ➤ Phosphoglycerate mutase
  • ➤ Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase
  • ➤ Triose phosphate isomerase
  • ➤ Aldolase
  • ➤ Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: All among the following are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arm span

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arm span can be used as an alternative method for measuring height, especially when direct height measurement is not feasible.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening abdominal pain and obstipation. He reports sustaining a blunt abdominal injury three days ago. On examination, he has a tense and tender abdomen with signs of guarding. The provided chest X-ray in the erect position shows an abnormal finding. Based on his history, clinical presentation, and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The X-ray image shows free air under the diaphragm, a classic radiographic sign of a hollow viscus perforation, most commonly caused by trauma, peptic ulcer disease, or bowel injury. In this case, the patient's history of blunt abdominal trauma, worsening pain, and obstipation strongly support the diagnosis.
  • • Key Points
  • • Key Points
  • • Radiographic Findings:
  • • Radiographic Findings:
  • • The presence of free air under the diaphragm in an erect chest X-ray is a typical finding indicative of a perforated hollow viscus.
  • • Clinical Presentation:
  • • Clinical Presentation:
  • • Patients with hollow viscus perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, obstipation, and signs of peritonitis, including tenderness, guarding, and signs of acute abdomen.
  • • The pain is usually worsened by movement, and systemic signs such as tachycardia, nausea, vomiting, and fever may also be present.
  • • Septic shock may develop in severe cases due to peritoneal contamination.
  • • Pathophysiology:
  • • Pathophysiology:
  • • Perforation of a hollow organ, such as the intestines or stomach, leads to leakage of air and contents into the peritoneal cavity, causing acute bacterial peritonitis. This inflammation can be localized or generalized and requires urgent management.
  • • Management:
  • • Management:
  • • The management of hollow viscus perforation involves surgical intervention, typically laparotomy, to repair the perforation and treat peritonitis.
  • • Supportive care includes pain management, fluid resuscitation, and antibiotics to control infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Acute pancreatitis: Typically presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and no free air under the diaphragm on imaging.
  • • Option
  • • A) Acute pancreatitis:
  • • Option C) Small bowel obstruction: Presents with abdominal distension, vomiting, and no free air under the diaphragm; air-fluid levels are more common.
  • • Option
  • • C) Small bowel obstruction:
  • • Option D) Traumatic splenic rupture: Would present with left upper quadrant pain, signs of hemorrhagic shock, and free fluid rather than free air on imaging.
  • • Option
  • • D) Traumatic splenic rupture:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation is a critical diagnosis characterized by abdominal pain, peritonitis, and the presence of free air under the diaphragm on imaging. Prompt surgical intervention is essential to prevent severe complications such as sepsis and death.

questions.text: Diabetic drug that should be stopped immediately with a creatinine of 5.6mg/dl? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metformin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metformin should be discontinued in patients with a creatinine level above 1.5 mg/dL for men and 1.4 mg/dL for women, or a GFR below 30 mL/min to avoid the risk of lactic acidosis, especially in the context of significant renal impairment.

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.
  • ➤ Ref -Dinesh Puri 3 rd e/pg. 393,
  • ➤ Ref -Dinesh Puri 3 rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified under epithelial cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian tumors originate from the cells that line the surface of the ovary. Clear cell carcinoma is a subtype of epithelial ovarian tumors.
  • • Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary
  • • Classification of ovarian tumors:
  • • Classification of ovarian tumors:
  • • Epithelial Cell Tumor Serous Mucinous Brenner Clear cell Endometrioid Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category. Germ Cell Tumor Dysgerminoma Yolk sac tumor Choriocarcinoma Teratoma Embryonal Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here. Sex Cord Stromal Tumor Granulosa cell tumor Thecoma Fibroma Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.
  • • Epithelial Cell Tumor Serous Mucinous Brenner Clear cell Endometrioid Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  • • Epithelial Cell Tumor
  • • Serous Mucinous Brenner Clear cell Endometrioid Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  • • Serous
  • • Serous
  • • Mucinous
  • • Mucinous
  • • Brenner
  • • Brenner
  • • Clear cell
  • • Clear cell
  • • Endometrioid
  • • Endometrioid
  • • Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  • • Clear cell carcinoma
  • • Germ Cell Tumor Dysgerminoma Yolk sac tumor Choriocarcinoma Teratoma Embryonal Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  • • Germ Cell Tumor
  • • Dysgerminoma Yolk sac tumor Choriocarcinoma Teratoma Embryonal Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  • • Dysgerminoma
  • • Dysgerminoma
  • • Yolk sac tumor
  • • Yolk sac tumor
  • • Choriocarcinoma
  • • Choriocarcinoma
  • • Teratoma
  • • Teratoma
  • • Embryonal
  • • Embryonal
  • • Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  • • Clear cell carcinoma
  • • Sex Cord Stromal Tumor Granulosa cell tumor Thecoma Fibroma Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.
  • • Sex Cord Stromal Tumor
  • • Granulosa cell tumor Thecoma Fibroma Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.
  • • Granulosa cell tumor
  • • Granulosa cell tumor
  • • Thecoma
  • • Thecoma
  • • Fibroma
  • • Fibroma
  • • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
  • • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
  • • Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.
  • • Clear cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified as an epithelial cell tumor.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 291, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 291, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group

options.label: C
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains

questions.correct_answer: A. The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with muscle weakness, fatigue, and persistent hypertension. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause of her symptoms. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Primary hyperaldosteronism is characterized by excessive aldosterone production, which leads to increased sodium reabsorption, potassium excretion, and hydrogen ion loss. This results in hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Conditions causing similar presentations include Liddle syndrome, apparent mineralocorticoid excess, and glucocorticoid remediable hyperaldosteronism, all of which involve aldosterone or mineralocorticoid receptor activation pathways.
  • • Common Causes of Hypokalemia + Hypertension:
  • • Common Causes of Hypokalemia + Hypertension:
  • • Liddle syndrome: ENaC channel gain-of-function mutation.
  • • Liddle syndrome:
  • • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess: Due to 11β-HSD loss of function, leading to increased cortisol stimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors.
  • • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess:
  • • Geller syndrome and GRA: Conditions involving abnormal aldosterone regulation.
  • • Geller syndrome and GRA:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Bartter syndrome: Characterized by hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but with normotension.
  • • Option
  • • A) Bartter syndrome:
  • • Option C) Gitelman syndrome: Presents with hypokalemia and alkalosis but also normotension.
  • • Option
  • • C) Gitelman syndrome:
  • • Option D) Gordon syndrome: Associated with hypertension and hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia.
  • • Option
  • • D) Gordon syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension is typically associated with conditions involving excessive aldosterone or mineralocorticoid receptor activity, such as primary hyperaldosteronism. Differentiating these conditions from syndromes that present with normotension or hyperkalemia is essential for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Moist heat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.
  • ➤ TYPES of SCALD INJURIES
  • ➤ TYPES of SCALD INJURIES
  • ➤ Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water. Accidental Splash burns Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.
  • ➤ Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.
  • ➤ Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.
  • ➤ Accidental Splash burns
  • ➤ Accidental Splash burns
  • ➤ Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.
  • ➤ Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a stable pregnant patient displaying Torsades de Pointes, especially in the context of pre-eclampsia, IV magnesium sulfate is the recommended treatment. It helps in both controlling the arrhythmia and providing prophylaxis against eclamptic seizures.

questions.text: Identify the cells marked in the given image? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Lymphocyte-1, Monocyte-4, Eosinophil-2, Basophil-3, Neutrophil -5
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymphocyte- 1, Monocyte-4, Eosinophil-2, Basophil-3, Neutrophil -5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulocytes:
  • ➤ Granulocytes:
  • ➤ Neutrophil - 3 to 5 lobed nucleus with small, bluish granules in the cytoplasm Eosinophil - Binucleate/spectacle shaped nuclei with brick-red granules in the cytoplasm Basophil- Large bluish granules in the cytoplasm which obscure the nucleus.
  • ➤ Neutrophil - 3 to 5 lobed nucleus with small, bluish granules in the cytoplasm
  • ➤ Eosinophil - Binucleate/spectacle shaped nuclei with brick-red granules in the cytoplasm
  • ➤ Basophil- Large bluish granules in the cytoplasm which obscure the nucleus.
  • ➤ Agranulocytes:
  • ➤ Agranulocytes:
  • ➤ Lymphocytes- size just larger than an BC. No granules, no nucleoli present. Monocytes - largest cells with a kidney-shaped nucleus.
  • ➤ Lymphocytes- size just larger than an BC. No granules, no nucleoli present.
  • ➤ Monocytes - largest cells with a kidney-shaped nucleus.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Enterogastric

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying. It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.
  • • Mechanism of enterogastric reflex
  • • Mechanism of enterogastric reflex
  • • Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.
  • • Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
  • • Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
  • • Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex : Incorrect. The gastrocolic reflex triggers increased colonic motility in response to food entering the stomach. It does not directly affect gastric emptying.
  • • Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex
  • • Option B. Enterocolic Reflex : Incorrect. This is not a widely recognized reflex within standard physiological texts; it does not pertain specifically to the control of gastric emptying.
  • • Option B. Enterocolic Reflex
  • • Option C. Gastroileal Reflex : Incorrect. The gastroileal reflex stimulates the movement of chyme from the ileum into the large intestine following food intake, which is unrelated to the initial inhibition of gastric emptying.
  • • Option C. Gastroileal Reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enterogastric reflex plays a critical role in regulating the rate at which the stomach empties its contents into the duodenum, particularly under conditions where the chyme is highly acidic. This regulation ensures that the duodenum can adequately process the chyme without being overwhelmed, which is crucial for maintaining digestive health and preventing duodenal irritation or damage.
  • ➤ Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex
  • ➤ Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex
  • ➤ Duodenal distension Irritation of the duodenal mucosa Acidity of the chyme Osmolality of the chyme Breakdown products of proteins and fats
  • ➤ Duodenal distension
  • ➤ Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  • ➤ Acidity of the chyme
  • ➤ Osmolality of the chyme
  • ➤ Breakdown products of proteins and fats

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.correct_answer: C. Toxin gene detection by PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

questions.text: Hormones secreted from A, B, C, D are respectively (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

options.label: B
options.text: A- Aldosterone, B- Androgen, C- Cortisol, D- Epinephrine

options.label: C
options.text: A- Aldosterone, B- Epinephrine, C- Androgen, D- Cortisol

options.label: D
options.text: A- Cortisol, B- Aldosterone, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

questions.correct_answer: A. A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal gland's zones and their respective hormones are:
  • ➤ Zona Glomerulosa : Aldosterone Zona Fasciculata : Cortisol Zona Reticularis : Androgens Adrenal Medulla : Epinephrine
  • ➤ Zona Glomerulosa : Aldosterone
  • ➤ Zona Glomerulosa
  • ➤ Zona Fasciculata : Cortisol
  • ➤ Zona Fasciculata
  • ➤ Zona Reticularis : Androgens
  • ➤ Zona Reticularis
  • ➤ Adrenal Medulla : Epinephrine
  • ➤ Adrenal Medulla

questions.text: Bilateral pedal edema is least likely to be associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic venous insufficiency is least likely to be associated with bilateral pedal edema compared to chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and chronic liver disease.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which agency offers seeds and manure as part of applied nutrition programs in schools? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) UNICEF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ UNICEF provides seeds, manure, and water supply equipment as part of its Applied Nutrition Program to develop school gardens, which are used in school feeding programs to improve children's nutrition.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Alogliptin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alogliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, is the most likely drug responsible for the increase in GLP-1 and GIP levels and the decrease in glucagon levels in this patient. It effectively lowers HbA1c levels and is administered orally, fitting the description provided.

questions.text: Which of the following given cancers rarely metastasize to the liver? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prostate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastasis. The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination via the portal venous system. The most relevant such metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after its complete resection.
  • ➤ The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of blunt trauma to his right eye sustained during a sports injury one week ago. He complains of blurred vision and photophobia but denies any pain. On slit-lamp examination, the clinician observes a faint circular opacity on the anterior surface of the lens, as shown in the image below. What is the finding marked by the arrow?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The marked finding in the image is a Vossius ring, which appears as a circular ring of pigmentation on the anterior surface of the lens. This ring is composed of brown amorphous pigment granules that imprint from the iris onto the lens capsule, typically following blunt trauma to the eye.
  • • Vossius Ring:
  • • Vossius Ring:
  • • A Vossius ring is caused by the forceful backward displacement of the cornea and iris during blunt trauma, which results in the iris imprinting onto the lens surface.
  • • It usually has the same diameter as the contracted pupil at the time of impact.
  • • Over time, the pigment can resorb, leaving behind discrete subcapsular opacities.
  • • Clinical Significance:
  • • Clinical Significance:
  • • A Vossius ring serves as an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye. It does not usually impair vision significantly but indicates the need for further evaluation of ocular damage that may have resulted from the injury.
  • • Management:
  • • Management:
  • • The Vossius ring itself often requires no specific treatment, but the underlying trauma necessitates a thorough ocular examination to assess for other potential injuries, such as hyphema, retinal detachment, or angle recession.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anterior subcapsular cataract: Opacities that form under the anterior lens capsule, typically associated with aging, trauma, or other ocular conditions, but they do not appear as a ring pattern.
  • • Option
  • • A. Anterior subcapsular cataract:
  • • Option C. Posterior synechiae: Adhesions between the iris and the lens, often seen in inflammatory conditions like uveitis, not related to blunt trauma in the pattern shown.
  • • Option
  • • C. Posterior synechiae:
  • • Option D. Corneal abrasion: Superficial damage to the corneal epithelium, seen as staining defects under fluorescein dye, not involving the lens.
  • • Option
  • • D. Corneal abrasion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Vossius ring is an imprint of the iris on the anterior lens surface, usually following blunt trauma to the eye. It serves as a key diagnostic clue of prior ocular injury and requires further evaluation to rule out additional trauma-related complications.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.
  • • Option A. Emergency LSCS:
  • • Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.
  • • Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS:
  • • Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.
  • • Option D. Tocolysis:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of bipolar disorder has recently been started on lithium therapy. During a follow-up visit, the healthcare provider wants to educate the patient on the signs of lithium toxicity. Which of the following side effects should the patient be instructed to monitor and report immediately as they may indicate lithium toxicity? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ataxia and Diarrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients on lithium therapy should be educated to monitor and immediately report signs of lithium toxicity, such as ataxia and diarrhea, to prevent serious adverse effects.
  • ➤ Mnemonic
  • ➤ Mnemonic
  • ➤ If DAT symptom is present, report to hospital:
  • ➤ DAT
  • ➤ D iarrhea A taxia T innitus
  • ➤ D iarrhea
  • ➤ D
  • ➤ A taxia
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ T innitus
  • ➤ T

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ADH specifically regulates the body's water balance by acting through aquaporin-2 channels in the kidney's collecting ducts, facilitating the reabsorption of water back into the bloodstream and thus concentrating the urine. This mechanism is crucial for maintaining proper hydration and electrolyte balance in the body.

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Entamoeba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized. Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages. An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm. Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • ➤ Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • ➤ An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • ➤ Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Attached to pelvic brim

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The levator ani is not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, it originates from the posterior surface of the body of the pubis, the obturator fascia, and the ischial spine. It then inserts into the coccyx, anococcygeal ligament, and walls of the prostate or vagina, rectum, and anal canal. The incorrect notion about its attachment to the pelvic brim is a common misconception.
  • • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament. Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve. Supports and raises the pelvic floor. Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.
  • • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • • Insertion :-
  • • Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • • Nerve supply:-
  • • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  • • Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Supports pelvic viscera : This statement is correct. The levator ani, along with other pelvic floor muscles, forms a supportive sling for the pelvic organs such as the bladder, uterus (in females), and rectum. This muscular support is essential for maintaining continence and facilitating functions such as micturition and defecation.
  • • Option A
  • • Supports pelvic viscera
  • • Option B. Converge downwards and medially : This statement is also correct. The fibers of the levator ani muscles, especially from the pubococcygeus, tend to converge towards the midline and run in a downward direction. This orientation provides the necessary support to the pelvic organs and creates a muscular barrier between the pelvic cavity and the perineum.
  • • Option B.
  • • Converge downwards and medially
  • • Option C. Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus : This statement is partially true. The levator ani is made up of three parts: the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus. All three parts contribute to the function and support provided by the levator ani. Thus, while the statement includes two components of the levator ani, it omits the puborectalis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pelvic brim is not connected to the levator ani muscle. It originates from the ischial spine, levator ani's arcus tendinous (a thickened section of the obturator fascia, and the pubic body.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe back pain that has progressively worsened over the past 10 days. He also reports new-onset urinary incontinence and difficulty walking. His medical history includes lumbar disc prolapse diagnosed previously. On examination, there is reduced sensation in the perineal area and weakness in both legs. There is no history of fever or weight loss. Considering his symptoms and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cauda equina syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cauda equina syndrome is a severe condition resulting from nerve compression in the lumbosacral spinal canal, commonly due to lumbar disc herniation. Recognizing the symptoms, such as severe back pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia, is critical, as prompt surgical intervention is essential to prevent permanent neurological damage

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coxiella burnetii cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. Serology for specific antibodies is the method used for its diagnosis. Giemsa stain is a versatile stain used to diagnose a variety of blood parasites and intracellular pathogen.

options.label: B

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Episiotomy scissors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum to facilitate childbirth and prevent severe perineal tears. Their use is restricted to specific obstetric situations to avoid unnecessary complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 755 Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: ( INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ptosis, particularly of the type seen in this patient, is typically caused by a dysfunction or disconnection of the levator muscle or its aponeurosis, either congenital or acquired.
  • ➤ Types:
  • ➤ Types:
  • ➤ Note: Pseudoptosis is apparent but not true drooping of the eyelid. Causes include lack of support of the lids by the globe (orbital volume deficit like an artificial eye, microphthalmos, or enophthalmos), contralateral lid retraction, ipsilateral hypotropia, brow ptosis, or dermatochalasis.

questions.text: An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts that were 4-8 µm in size. The image is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cryptosporidium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptosporidium oocysts are small (4-8 µm) coccidian parasites responsible for causing diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They are identified in stool samples by their size and acid-fast staining properties.

questions.text: The most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis is? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Morphology

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The morphology of sperm is considered the most important marker of male fertility. While sperm concentration and progressive motility are valuable for distinguishing between fertile and infertile men, strict sperm morphology is the most discriminating factor in assessing male fertility potential.
  • • Morphological abnormalities in spermatozoa can be identified in various parts, including the head, neck, mid-piece, and tail. These abnormalities can result from defective spermatogenesis or certain epididymal pathologies, leading to increased morphological defects in the sperm. Spermatozoa with abnormal morphology have a lower fertilizing potential, making morphology a critical parameter in semen analysis for determining fertility.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Concentration: Sperm concentration is an important parameter, but it is not as critical as morphology in predicting fertility. The WHO 2021 standard for sperm concentration is 16 million/ml.
  • • Option B. Concentration:
  • • Option C. Motility: Progressive motility is significant, with the WHO 2021 standard being 30%, but it is not the most crucial parameter compared to morphology.
  • • Option C. Motility:
  • • Option D. Sperm Count: While total sperm count is important, it is encompassed under concentration and motility measures. Morphology remains the most critical individual parameter.
  • • Option D. Sperm Count:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sperm morphology is the most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis, as it directly correlates with the fertilizing potential of the sperm.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg443, https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg443,
  • ➤ https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) C2A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease. For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.
  • ➤ The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, suspected to be due to an intestinal obstruction. The clinical team decides to insert a nasogastric (NG) tube for gastric decompression. The nurse asks about the correct technique to measure the appropriate length of the NG tube for proper placement. What is the most appropriate method to measure the placement of the nasogastric tube?

options.label: A
options.text: Measure from the tip of the nose to the mid-sternum.

options.label: B
options.text: Measure from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule, then down to the xiphisternum.

options.label: C
options.text: Insert the tube until resistance is met, then pull back slightly.

options.label: D
options.text: Measure from the mouth to the belly button.

questions.correct_answer: B. Measure from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule, then down to the xiphisternum.
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Measure from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule, then down to the xiphisternum.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The N-E-X method is the standard technique for measuring the length of a nasogastric tube, ensuring it reaches the stomach without complications. Proper measurement, placement confirmation, and patient positioning are essential to safely and effectively manage NG tube use.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IgE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgE is the immunoglobulin responsible for mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions , such as anaphylaxis, which can occur in response to bee stings or other allergens.
  • ➤ IgE
  • ➤ type I hypersensitivity reactions
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 373
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 373

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vincristine

Explanation:

  • • Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation
  • • Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation : Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • • Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation
  • • Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation : Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.
  • • Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation
  • • Options D. Vincristine: Explanation : Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.
  • • Options D. Vincristine: Explanation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?(NEET PG 2020)

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acitretin is not contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia, although lipid levels should be monitored during therapy. The drug increases sensitivity to sunlight, requires women to avoid pregnancy for 3 years after therapy due to its teratogenicity, and has a long half-life of about 50 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding disulfiram? 1. Stops alcohol craving 2. Accumulates acetaldehyde 3. Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase 4. Starting dose is 250 mg
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.  1 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Disulfiram does not reduce alcohol cravings; it works by causing adverse reactions when alcohol is consumed, thereby discouraging drinking. It inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, not alcohol dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and subsequent unpleasant symptoms. The starting dose for disulfiram therapy is typically 250 mg per day.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endothelial injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thrombosis is primarily initiated by endothelial injury, which is a key component of the Virchow triad and leads to the subsequent activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.
